After the morning passes, you will be gazing over the rainforest the early afternoon, watching the mist swirl and imagining tomorrow’s adventure.

dayInfo.title: Volcanoes National Park – Two Days of Intimate Gorilla Trekking
dayInfo.description: Through the green, you will see a blanket of black fur. A gorilla is on the move, crawling on all fours through the rainforest. It will take an hour of trekking to get here. Now, you must continue the journey, and the guide will slice a path with a machete. Only after 30 minutes will the gorillas stop, and you will have reached your destination. You will approach slowly as a gorilla mother gazes out and greets you before uttering a grunt of approval. You can creep even closer, walking up to the rest of the troop. A dozen gorillas will appear before you, including a playful youngster swinging about the trees. Officially, you can come to within seven meters, but the gorillas do not know this. Some of them start feeding behind you. For 30 minutes, it will be as if you are in a dream with so much going on that it will be hard to know where to focus. The second half of the encounter will be more relaxed, especially once you put the camera away. You will admire different behaviors and sounds, especially how the gorillas interact with each other. There will be time to focus on an individual, particularly the cute gestures and calls that it makes. Slowly you will come to know an entire troop, and then, it will be time to return, trekking back through the rainforest and away from these unique primates. This is too unique of an experience to only do once. So, the next morning you will return, trekking to a different troop and experiencing the behavior of another gorilla family. It will be more relaxed the second time around, especially now that you know how gorilla trekking works. This time it will be a larger troop with two silverbacks and a slightly different social structure. You will stare in awe and wonder at the primates for an hour, feeling the inimitability of who you are with and sensing the remoteness of the rainforest. There are only around 1,000 mountain gorillas left, and none of them have ever been captive. When you return to the lodge, it will be rather special to think that you have encountered two of the few remaining troops.

dayInfo.title: Kigali – Cultural Encounters On Route to the Capital
dayInfo.description: Rwanda is a country on the rise and where welcoming local people reflect a nation of change. This is a country that confounds many preconceptions, and guides will be keen to show you its local side, particularly in villages on route to Kigali. With a full day to travel back to Kigali, you can take it slow and personalize an itinerary that is based on your interests.

dayInfo.title: Kigali – Departure
dayInfo.description: After a leisurely breakfast, you will fly from Kigali, which is one of East Africa’s major airports.

tourName: The Great Migration Photo Safari to Tanzania
placesVisited: Arusha, Tarangire, Lake Manyara National Park, Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Serengeti National Park
generalInfo: Experience the visual euphoria of Northern Tanzania on this 13-day safari adventure. Tailor-made for photo enthusiasts, this itinerary will bring indelible close-ups, unforgettable panoramas, and inspiring natural scenes. Explore six different national parks and gently succumb to the natural charms of Tanzania's untamed wildernesses. Then relive it all on your camera roll.

dayInfo.title: Arusha - Your African Adventure Begins
dayInfo.description: You will land at Kilimanjaro Airport in Arusha to start your African adventure. On a clear day, the views from the lodge are outstanding, the snow-capped peaks of Kilimanjaro and Mt Meru towering over the surrounding savannah. With birds singing from the lush treetops, this is an idyllic place to overcome any jet lag. As you settle into Tanzania you'll notice that everything moves with a relaxed rhythm. Enjoy a guided bird-watching walk, go horseback riding through the vivid landscape, or take a canoe onto the serene Lake Duluti. Tanzania's indelible mammals make their first appearance with, giraffes, and zebras greeting you on a full day game drive through Arusha National Park. First day safaris are always a bit of a blur, the day racing by as Africa's great wildlife is seen in the flesh for the first time. Everyone has seen photos or video before. But it's different to see it all from just a few meters away. Buffalos stare and stamp their hooves, showing off their one-ton frames and bushy hair. Black and white Colobus monkeys and blue monkeys swing through branches, showing remarkable agility as they cheekily pass by. And giraffes really are taller than the trees.

dayInfo.title: Tarangire National Park - Immersed in the Wonders
dayInfo.description: Great herds mark the Tarangire woodlands, up to 300 elephants moving together as they plod past ancient baobab trees. It's an iconic scene, elephant and baobab juxtaposed in one of Africa's finest parks, and it's a scene that will accompany you throughout these two days in Tarangire. Olive baboons and waterbuck also move effortlessly across the woodland, while a cacophony of birdsong sails across the treetops. Yellow-collared lovebirds are probably the loudest, and they're just one of 550 different bird species that congregate here. Some are pretty, some sing duets, like the red-and-yellow barbet, and then some impress with their size, including the nine foot wingspan of the Kori bustard. Tarangire has a raw and rugged landscape, scorched and dusty in dry season, fresh and vivid during the rainy season. And the views will continue all day and night, with your lodge offering spectacular panoramas and quaint accommodation. Elephants regularly pass right by, joined by a congregation of oryx and zebra. So sit back, admire the wonders of untamed Africa, and listen to the unique sounds of nature. But don't get too relaxed, two full days of thrilling safari will reveal all corners of Tarangire. Wildlife spotting is easy, the immense Tarangire River quenching the thirst of all its residents. Impala and hartebeest sip greedily in herds, relying on the vigilant look-out of others. Gazelle and eland are also out drinking, scratching along the shriveled riverbeds and swamps. Don't worry if these antelope species sound unfamiliar now, you'll quickly learn the nuances and how to distinguish each variety. In particular, look out for the rare long-necked gerenuk, standing on their hind legs and craning their necks towards overhanging branches. There are predators here, lots of them, and you'll find them in strange places. Admire the baobab trees and acacia woodland, photographing a landscape that looks as African as all the wildlife documentaries. All seems calm. But wait...was that something moving in the tree? Get closer and it appears to be nothing. You're just 10 meters away now, scanning the branches for movement, and then a lucid pair of eyes makes you jump. The lion has been watching you. They climb trees all over Tarangire, camouflaging themselves and then pouncing on prey. Leopards also prowl along these branches, and witnessing these two stealthy predators is a highlight of being in the park.

dayInfo.title: Lake Manyara - The Majestic Lake Manyara
dayInfo.description: Each Tanzanian park is different, ensuring that every game drive brings a fresh perspective and new experience. A meandering trail takes you through the Lake Manyara forest, each turn revealing something that lurks in the shadows. Perhaps you’ll spot a troop of baboons; mothers cradling babies and skipping across the red ground, old males reclining against a tree. Or maybe an elephant, appearing from nowhere and standing almost within touching distance. You'll drive slowly through the forest, each corner bringing surprise, and each tree a possible resting place for the tree-climbing lion. Lake Manyara is nestled into the base of the Great Rift Valley escarpment, and its forest is combined with a hippo infested lake and elephant covered floodplain. After leaving Tarangire you'll first stop at Mto Wa Mbu, a traditional Maasai village full of endearing sights; it's hard to leave without being energized by the color and imbued by their fierce continuation of tradition. More colors mark Lake Manyara, bright shocks of blue and red amongst the park's remarkable concentration of bird species. They flutter around the lake, joined by the hippos that wade through the shallows and then lope along the muddy banks. Alpha males jockey for mating rights, while youngsters rest their heads on a mother's humongous back. Lake Manyara is relatively small for a national park, but its combination of ecosystems and diverse collection of wildlife make this an action-packed day.

dayInfo.title: Lake Eyasi - Nature and Culture
dayInfo.description: Tanzania's remarkable residents don't just come on four legs. Indigenous hunter-gatherer tribes still exist in East Africa and you'll enjoy two days of memorable cultural immersion. The nimble Hadzape Bushmen sidestep through the trees, picking up on every clue as they stalk a small antelope. You can also see the clues; an upturned stone, a line of animal droppings, a slight indent in the grass. But the bushman spots them without breaking stride, eyes always scanning ahead, the path of the prey continually visualized. On day eight you'll head out on a morning hunt, a haunting experience that reveals the phenomenal skills of these ancient people. And yes, they do still use a homemade bow and arrow. Your tented camp offers surreal views over Lake Eyasi, a shallow salt lake that rises and falls with the rains. There are just seven spacious tents, each with a private verandah, en-suite bathroom with hot water, and thatched roof. Just like the local tribes, the camp is all about carefully co-existing with the environment. This is a place of tranquility, harmony, and getting involved with local tribes. The Hadzape hunter-gatherers use an ancient click dialect, while the waDatonga villages remain unchanged for millennia. Walking to nearby natural springs and ambling around the lake will also bring interaction with local villagers.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Crater - The Coffee Farms of the Great Rift Valley
dayInfo.description: How many times have you bought coffee that claims to be “the freshest?” It can't really come any fresher than the coffee from the charming coffee plantations of the Great Rift Valley. Enjoy lunch in a rustic farmhouse, reveling in the mystique of an old era and the enchanting smells of the plantations. Your camp is a wonderful spot to spend a relaxed morning, touring the farm, savoring the food, and relishing the views. From here you'll visit the Tioma Village School, hundreds of enthusiastic children providing a memorable welcome. Overnight will be at your next lodge, perched on the western rim of Ngorongoro Crater.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Crater - The Remarkable World
dayInfo.description: Ngorongoro Crater is a photographer's dream, the wildlife appearing from all angles and at all times. It's difficult to know which way to point the camera as the crater floor teems with unique scenes. Buffalo herds chew and chomp their way through the grass beside you. Flamingos cover the lake, shocks of pink wonderfully contrasted with the vivid blue water. But turn around quickly and a pride of lions are on the hunt, slowly walking through the grass as they target a large herd of watchful wildebeest. There's a popular conception that great wildlife photography takes lots of patience. In many places it does. Ngorongoro wildlife is unlike anywhere else on the planet and because of the sheer concentration of wildlife, you need to be prepared at all times! Your accommodations overlook the crater with private verandahs gazing down on a unique biosphere. From here you can see it all; the verdant woodland, open grassland, parched riverbeds, and the far walls of this inactive volcanic caldera. This is one of Africa's best lodges, mixing tradition and style with luxury and charm. Huge elephant bulls and small zebra herds are amongst the cast that like to wander past the lodge in the evening. Gaze down onto nature's great amphitheater and then descend the steep crater walls into the heart of the action. On most game drives you hope to see lions. In Ngorongoro these ferocious predators are part of the scenery, and spotting them out on a hunt is a real possibility. Some prides lounge in the sun, bellies full, eyes half-closed, beautiful black manes out on display. Others are hungry, the females ducking into the grass as they eye up a meal. Don't stare at them for too long though, because over your shoulder could be a cheetah or hyena. Out in the forest is a kind of elephant retirement home, some of the continent's largest males plodding a lone track through the trees, cast out from the herd but enjoying the bounty of Ngorongoro. Keep exploring and there are the hippos that prowl the lake shore, or the dazzling horns of the hartebeest herds. Then one sight brings about silence in the safari truck. A pair of endangered black rhinos approach the clearing, slowly, unhurried, watchful. Their power is evident, their horns are expectantly majestic, yet their grace comes as a surprise. Before the cameras come out there's a moment when everyone just watches and admires, these breathtaking animals witnessed first-hand. Ngorongoro Crater is the best place in Tanzania to spot Black rhinos.

dayInfo.title: Southern Serengeti - Spectacular Show
dayInfo.description: Few places in the world can stir the emotion like the Serengeti. The grass plains seem to stretch for eternity, going beyond the horizon and dotted with giant herds of wildebeest and zebra. This is where the Great Migration takes place, an annual journey of some two million mammals, dictated by the rains and followed by a hungry cast of predators. The migration is happening all year round, the animals always in search of fresh grazing land. For the next two days you'll be in the south east of this immense park, staying at your next lodge, neatly situated just outside the park boundary and away from the tourist crowds. From here the immense plains wow the eyes, vistas extending into the distance from your private verandah, and elephants approaching a nearby waterhole. Before reaching the lodge you'll have a short stop in Olduvai Gorge, the cradle of humankind where man's earliest ancestral remains have been found. It's a poignant and thought provoking experience. In the early months of the year the wildebeest congregate around this corner of the Serengeti, giving birth and raising young on the profuse grass. It's a particularly abundant time for predators. Cheetahs accelerate and pounce, the defenseless wildebeest unable to prevent regular attacks. Lion prides peacefully coexist, while hyenas and jackals scrounge for scraps. At all times of year the sheer concentration of wildlife is difficult to believe. Giraffes amble along the horizon, their necks silhouetted against a burning sunset. Thompson's gazelle seem to pop up everywhere, while circling vultures reveal the location of a recent kill. With morning and afternoon game drives you'll be overwhelmed by the sights of the Serengeti. Even a quick stop for a picnic is accompanied by a pool full of wading hippos.

dayInfo.title: Western Serengeti - Exploring Western Corridor
dayInfo.description: Every journey in the Serengeti is a safari. A game drive on day 11 will take you across the park, passing lounging lions, roaming elephants, and the continual array of watchful antelopes. It takes a journey across the park to truly reveal the scale of the Serengeti. The grassland never stops; it just keeps going and going. The Kirawira Serena is idyllically situated, towering over the famous western corridor, on the route of the marauding wildebeest. They pass through here between April and June, although the exact dates will vary each year. And remember, it takes a long time for two million mammals to pass by, so don’t be worried about turning up a day late. Giant herds dot the plains, covering them in a patchwork quilt of black. From a distance it's a surreal sight, and there's a good chance that you'll be seeing it from the elegance of this exclusive camp. Each tent comes with a personal valet, a four-poster bed, antique Edwardian furniture, and the ongoing sounds of the Serengeti. These are your last two days on safari and the wonders will continue. Nowhere in Tanzania is the same, and every game drive brings new delights. In the Serengeti there's always grass, gazelle, wildebeest, and predators. On some drives the lions lie in the shade of your safari truck. On others it's a leopard that's most memorable, its solemn movements towards prey showcasing intelligence and beauty. Then on the drive back to camp a pair of elephants starts fighting in front of your eyes. And throughout it all the landscape provides a breathtaking beauty, a stunning backdrop that screams of untamed Africa and aches with authenticity. For an alternative vista, an optional morning balloon ride can be taken on day 14. For an idyllic final evening, ask your valet for a hammock and watch everything unfold. As always in the Serengeti, keep the camera ready...you never can predict what time something might wander past the camp.

dayInfo.title: Arusha - Return to Arusha and Depart from Tanzania
dayInfo.description: Savor your last morning waking up in the wilderness. Say goodbye to the wildlife that surrounds the camp, and then take some final photos as you're transferred to the nearby airstrip. On the local scheduled flight you'll get a new impression of the Serengeti's scale, before landing in Arusha and enjoying a leisurely afternoon at the Mountain Village. Note that a maximum weight of 30 pounds is permitted on this flight. It's possible to leave some of your luggage at the Mountain Lodge before you set off on safari on day four. At 5pm you'll depart for Kilimanjaro Airport for your home-bound flight. How long will it be before you return for another Tanzanian safari adventure? Or, consider adding on to your adventure.

tourName: The Lion King Inspired Safari for Families
placesVisited: Kilimanjaro, Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Olduvai Gorge, Serengeti, Nairobi, Hell’s Gate National Park
generalInfo: Perhaps no production has done more to excite children's wildlife imaginations than The Lion King . While the movie is an animation, it's all inspired by the safari destinations of East Africa, such as the Serengeti (Pride Lands) and Olduvai Gorge, where Mufasa was trampled. This family safari follows the journey of the boy who would be king, revealing all the iconic settings. Featuring eleven days of safari, it's a charming immersion in the wildlife world behind the fiction.

dayInfo.title: Kilimanjaro Region – Inspired by the Opening Credits and the Circle of Life
dayInfo.description: The movie's opening credits reveal three of Africa's most remarkable landscapes. Birds flutter above Victoria Falls, mammals march across the Okavango Delta, and elephants roam beneath the snow-capped volcanic peak of Mount Kilimanjaro. The first two settings are actually in Southern Africa, far from the landscape that the Pride Lands are based upon. But Kilimanjaro immediately inspires, causing a gasp as your family lands at Kilimanjaro International Airport and gazes across at the summit. There are few better introductions to Africa's wonders. You're greeted at the airport and transferred to a nearby lodge, where the calm and exotic gardens help everyone recharge after the flight. Dinner at the lodge is included.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Crater – Hakuna Matata – The Carefree Land of Simba and a Warthog
dayInfo.description: When the boy king is banished, he's revived from near death by a warthog and a meerkat (here's another inconsistency with reality as meerkats are not residents in this area). Together they sing about Hakuna Matata , a wonderful phrase concerning trouble-free living. This phrase comes directly from the Swahili language and is frequently used by locals to say “no worries.” As the two guides lead you into Ngorongoro Crater, you quickly learn how it wasn't just local landscapes and animals that inspired the movie. The Swahili language fills the script: Simba translates as lion, Pumba is a colloquialism for warthog, Mufasa means king in some Swahili dialects, and Shenzi (the name of the lead hyena) translates as a mix of barbarous and uncouth. Simba and his two new friends live in a carefree world, one that is very much like Ngorongoro Crater. Giant elephant bulls inhabit the forest here, their proud tusks rising above the eyes of a retired patriarch. Flamingos create a pink tinge on the lake while hippos barge across the grass. Zebras and buffalos congregate on grassland that's hemmed in by the crater walls, excitable herds that always provide charming views. Lion prides are spotted, often resting beneath the tree as they sleep off the tree. A handful of black rhinos trot across the crater floor; only 1,000 remain in the wild, so if they make an appearance, you know that the destination is bountiful for almost everyone. This no worries landscape is an idyllic introduction to an African safari as it brings encounters with a wide diversity of animals in a single five-hour game drive. You'll explore in the afternoon, departing at sunset to a quiet lodge that's often visited by elephants during the evening.

dayInfo.title: Olduvai Gorge to Serengeti – Where the Wildebeest Trample Mufasa
dayInfo.description: The road descends from Ngorongoro to the Serengeti, giving everyone their first glimpse of the pride lands. A dramatic scar slices through the plains, the stark walls of Olduvai Gorge providing the inspiration behind the wildebeest stampede. There are few animals here (food is scarce in comparison to the plains), but the resemblance to the movie is almost pixel-perfect. Take your photos then discover the real history to the gorge. Olduvai has uncovered the earliest evidence of human ancestors, possessing magnificent antiquities like skulls and tools that reveal the evolutionary chain of homo sapiens. Walking through the gorge has both movie moments and a surreal evocation of the past. After lunch, you continue the drive, descending onto the pride lands and finding a landscape of bounty. It's lush and green, the herds grazing in large numbers as they scatter across the plains. An elephant ambles past, a thousand zebra return your stare, wildebeest graze on strips of longer grass, and there's a continual sense that lions are always nearby. Up ahead you see them, a pride draped across a clump of yellow rocks that rise above the Serengeti plains. This is known as a kopje , although the children are likely to immediately exclaim that they've found Pride Rock. But a little further on there's another kopje. And another. So which is the highest and pointiest that the movie is modeled upon? The next few days will unravel the mystery.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti – Beautiful Family Safari in the Pride Lands
dayInfo.description: The Serengeti inspires from every angle, Tanzania's flagship safari destination as resplendent from up close as it was on the movie screen. It's difficult to find an angle that doesn't resemble the pride lands, and soon you realize that everything the light touches is now your kingdom, a mammoth landscape that always offers fresh safari scenes. Within a couple of days, the children's tick-list is answered. A leopard hiding in the branches of an acacia tree, hippos yawning at the waterhole, giraffe loping past with manifest elegance, and great crowds of wildebeest ignited into action. Hyenas snarl and startle the wildebeest (much like in the movie) and when one starts running, the whole herds start kicking up dust. During these three days, the game drive itinerary is flexible. Choose morning and late-afternoon drives to maximize the most dramatic wildlife encounters, or spend the whole day on safari, stopping for a picnic beside a lion-filled kopje or hippo-filled lake. You stay in a small luxury camp with sweeping views over the plains that have interconnected suites and a private verandah. Local Masai warriors run tailored children's activities at the camp's Masai Academy, teaching the basics of animal tracking, bush survival, and tribal customs. This can be particularly useful when you want a quiet afternoon. The camp is often surrounded by wildlife, and you don't need to travel far to see it all. Zebras graze on the grass outside the boutique tents, a herd of Thomson's gazelles skips past at breakfast, and the odd elephant picks at a nearby fruit tree while you're eating dinner. An expressive landscape like the Serengeti deserves a few days. At first, you're amazed by the similarities, matching the plains to the pride lands. During the movie, there are baffling shots of animals marching past in unison, or thousands of mammals congregating beneath the protruding rocks. It doesn't look real in the movie. It feels even less real when you get to see it. Rather than thousands, there are tens of thousands of mammals in a single panorama. Three hyenas become 30 hyenas. Every day, you're likely to encounter at least a couple of lion prides as the landscape is divided into unmarked territories. Drive next to a pride and the lionesses wake from slumber before roaming to the vehicle. They inspect you, gazing back into your eyes before deciding to sleep in the shade created by the back wheel. Here's the other Serengeti highlight: you don't just see the quantity and diversity of mammals; your family will also get exceptionally close.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti to Nairobi – A Final Day in the Pride Lands
dayInfo.description: In the morning, a final memory. It rumbles from the distance, a deep grunt that echoes towards the breakfast table, that of a large male lion roaring with pride. It's as heart-thumping as hearing it on the movie when you were seven years old. On a relaxed morning, you can have a final game drive on the pride lands before flying from a Serengeti airstrip back to Kilimanjaro International Airport. Here, you depart from Tanzania on a flight to Nairobi, Kenya's capital. Touch down and a new guide greets you at the airport for the short transfer to Karen, a lush green suburb on the outskirts of the city. The wildlife doesn't stop, and it's often possible to see giraffe necks and skyscrapers in the same city vista.

dayInfo.title: Nairobi – Meeting Giraffe and Elephants Who Could Have Been Extras
dayInfo.description: From a children's perspective, there's often a desire to get even closer. To pet a lion, to stroke a leopard's cute fur, to feel a zebra's mane. But this is wild Africa, and such things are as dangerous as anything on the continent. Today the children (and parents) do get to meet and interact with a few animals, starting with a visit to the Giraffe Centre in Karen. Endangered Rothschild Giraffes are rehabilitated here, and they will eat directly from the hand, stretching a long black tongue to slurp up little pellets. They're calm and quiet, satisfying many children's imaginations. At the Daphne Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage, a similar experience is possible with another giant, including the iconic feeling of a trunk coming over your shoulder and curling up before your eyes. Both these places are visited on a relaxed day in the city.

dayInfo.title: Hell's Gate National Park – Walking and Cycling Safari in the Park That Inspired the Animators
dayInfo.description: To animate a wild animal, you must understand their movements. Not just their famous gallops, but their facial expressions and sudden behavioral changes. A team of animators based themselves in Kenya's Hell's Gate National Park for three weeks. You'll only have two days, but the proximity to wildlife quickly reveals why this park was chosen. There are no lions or leopards here. Nor elephants. Roaming beneath beautiful canyon walls are the plains animals, like wildebeest, zebra, giraffe, buffalo, gazelle and hartebeest. A surreal number of monkeys and baboons also inhabit the compact park. Without predators, they all graze and live in peace, without fear of anything that passes. So when you walk up, the animals rarely move. Approach slowly and silently, and you could be just two or three meters away. To get closer, you explore on foot and on a bicycle, fresh safari activities that keep the children's imagination animated. Paddle past a zebra herd, walk past a tower of giraffes and get so close that you feel you could reach out and touch (although this isn't recommended as the animals will quickly run away). Such regular proximity was a learning experience for the animators and now becomes a playground of delight for your family. A new character from the movie is also found here – that of Rafiki (incidentally, the name translates as friend in Swahili). On the big screen, he's a mix of baboon and black and white colobus monkey, a friendly fellow with a mischievous attitude and an inclination towards laughter. In Hell's Gate, you'll see both and admire how they selected the best features of the two animals. During these two days, you stay at a lodge on the banks of nearby Lake Naivasha, where serene evenings are enhanced by the sight of hippos emerging from the water. Floodlights give you a premier view as the hippos graze just a few meters from the lodge (an electric fence had to be erected to stop the hippos from getting too close). It's very easy to imagine that this was the lake where Simba saw a vision of his father. Throughout the day, there are flexible safaris in Hell's Gate National Park, with a local guide leading you on walking and cycling safaris. His knowledge and experience help you get indelibly close to most of the animals, including the boisterous buffalos. Hell's Gate is a two-hour drive from Nairobi.

dayInfo.title: Hell’s Gate National Park to Nairobi – Departure
dayInfo.description: It's a two-hour drive from Hell's Gate back to Nairobi, the children waving farewell to giraffes and zebras as you exit the park and cruise through the Great Rift Valley. In this remarkable piece of Africa, it's possible to see wild animals from the main road, an indication of just how untouched East Africa remains. The guides will drop you at Nairobi International Airport with plenty of time before your intercontinental departure.

tourName: The Tanzanian Safari of Adventure and Romance
placesVisited: Lake Manyara National Park, Tarangire National Park, Ngorongoro Crater Conservation Area, Serengeti National Park
generalInfo: Safari revelry combines with romantic reverie on this unique Tanzanian safari for couples. Untamed thrills and adventure of exploring epic animal kingdoms combine with the personalized bliss of an idyllic private getaway. Tree houses above a waterhole, candlelit dinners amidst elephants, safari views from your own verandah; this vacation has been expertly crafted to ensure romance thrives in the heart of nature's greatest animal show.

dayInfo.title: Arusha – Landing Beside Mount Kilimanjaro
dayInfo.description: It's an iconic start as the plane touches down in Moshi, the snowcapped peak of Mount Kilimanjaro standing proud above the landscape. Kilimanjaro International Airport ensures you're catapulted straight into the heart of Tanzania's wilderness, with no time lost traveling by land across the country. Africa is probably a long way from home, so this first day is gentle and free. A chauffeur is waiting for you in arrivals and he transfers you to your hotel. You have a deluxe suite, so rest, relax, and get ready for the safari adventure that starts tomorrow.

dayInfo.title: Lake Manyara – A Treehouse and First Safari Impressions
dayInfo.description: Weave through the forest and the first safari impressions arrive like flashes from a dream. There's a baboon troop sauntering across the track, and here are three elephants bulldozing a path through the trees, and then you turn another corner to spot wild giraffe for the first time. These initial incursions into safari wilderness can sometimes be too much to take in. You're admiring a pod of hippos and then the guide grabs your attention. Turn around and half-hidden in the trees is a rare tree-climbing lion. Lake Manyara provides the perfect start to a Tanzanian safari adventure. An eclectic selection of classic safari sights is available in a compact and easy to explore the national park. Manyara doesn't have the huge herds or abundance of big cat hunting scenes, but that doesn't matter on your first safari. Most people are completely engulfed with the realism of the experience; you're just meters away from many of Africa's famous wild animals. Tonight's accommodation gives a glimpse at what to expect. Settle into a cute treehouse accessible by walkways suspended above the wilderness. Gaze out at a waterhole and watch the parade of visiting nomads; antelope herds, zebra, elephants, unusual four-legged characters impressing with their antics. It's a sight that's available from the bed, as well as from your private balcony. As you settle into the romantic bliss there's an accompanying soundtrack; birdsong that flutters through the branches, an occasional lion roar, elephants trampling and rustling, random calls from passing baboons. And this is just the start of this Tanzanian safari vacation for couples.

dayInfo.title: Tarangire – Unforgettable Safari and Romantic Bliss
dayInfo.description: Safari immersion is almost absolute on this unique vacation. Open your eyes, open the curtains, and the wandering herds are surrounding the waterhole. Just south of Manyara is Tarangire National Park, your base for the next three days, and the start of your Tanzania safari tour . Everyone is expecting the unadulterated excitement of a Tanzanian safari, but this vacation will also bring the romantic bliss of any iconic getaway. You're staying at a sumptuous lodge with just 12 luxury en suite tents on stilts. Intimate, exclusive, idyllic; this is an escape that provides unlimited private time with your partner. Except you're not completely alone; you're accompanied by huge herds of elephants, rowdy predators, and an almost complete cast of Africa's famous animals. Don't be put off by the word “tent.” This isn't camping as you may know it. Lavish king-sized beds gaze out onto the wilderness, the furnishings offer a classic African style, and the en-suite bathroom is wonderfully surrounded by the wild. You'll probably hear the elephants while having a shower. Then there's the infinity swimming pool and the verandah overlooking a waterhole. But pull yourself away from this romantic indulgence and over these three days, you'll discover all corners of an inimitable national park. The landscape is defined by two natural wonders. Giant baobab trees are everywhere, towering over meandering rivers and home to many more tree-climbing lions. Elephant herds are the second iconic sight. They travel by the hundreds, huge tuskers accompanying the trunk flapping babies and watchful mothers. Like each destination on this itinerary, the safari itinerary is flexible and tailored to your preferences. Each game drive is private and accompanied by an expert guide with an intimate knowledge of the environment. Perhaps you want a full day of exploring with a picnic beside hippo pools as an interlude? Or, maybe a sunrise game drive seeking out leopards on a hunt? Or is it the towering giraffe you have a particular fascination with? Three days in Tarangire not only provides a calming escape, it ensures a relaxed and easy pace that can satisfy the most idiosyncratic of safari dreams. Slowly you explore the trees, using the binoculars to scan the branches. A tail swishes, the leaves rustle, and there's the sight you've spent the morning searching for; a tree-climbing lion jumping down and starting to stalk its prey.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Crater – Completing the Safari Tick List
dayInfo.description: Have you ever watched a wildlife documentary and felt it bordered on the fictional? Like when rhinos charge lions who are hunting zebra that are being watched by hyenas? Can you really see something like this, or does it require two years of patient filming? Ngorongoro often feels like a surreal documentary. Descend the steep crater walls and begin exploring the distinct ecosystems; forests hiding elephants, grasslands patrolled by lions, a lake covered by wallowing flamingos. Which way do you look? A rhino causes you both to stop and stare, its inherent grace complimenting an unquestionable power. Eyes follow the horn, but something in the periphery pulls you both away. Now you’re admiring a large herd of buffalo, their bushy frames stampeding towards the safari truck. Why are they panicking? Keep watching and you spot three mischievous lionesses seeking a way to isolate a young calf. You'll leave Tarangire in the morning, saying farewell to the huge elephant herds and arriving at your lodge in time for a filling lunch. The whole crater extends beneath your feet and a zigzagging downhill trail takes you into this majestic realm of nature. Stay in the crater until sunset and then spend the evening around a crackling fire, admiring the stars and listening to the calls of the wild. Just as you’re about to cuddle up in bed, a lone elephant bull rumbles past your room. Maybe it's worth staying up for a few more minutes. Like all accommodation on this itinerary, your room is isolated and private; there are no other visitors interrupting the natural immersion and no need to share your piece of Tanzania with anyone else.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti – Into the Renowned Serengeti
dayInfo.description: There are a couple of options this morning. You may feel like a second game drive in Ngorongoro Crater, the dawn hours perfect for spotting big cats out on a hunt. Or you might want to head straight to the Serengeti and continue the lion spotting there. As always, this is a flexible itinerary that responds to your mood. So you may prefer a leisurely morning in bed, a champagne breakfast served on your private verandah, and the camera at the ready to snap passing ungulates. Today's drive takes you into the Southeastern corner of the Serengeti. Wildebeest are everywhere, their wiry frames mingling with herds of zebra and thousands upon thousands of Thompson's gazelle. The grasslands seem to stretch for eternity, a carpet of green dotted with four-legged residents. This is just the view from your private verandah. Yet you're going to spend five days in this world-famous park, so expect these ubiquitous first impressions to become an iconic backdrop that frames the whole experience. There will be time for a short afternoon game drive, as well as a lazy evening absorbing the silhouettes of beauty that cross the horizon.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti – Crossing the Planet's Most Impressive Animal World
dayInfo.description: Today you journey across the planet's most impressive animal kingdom. Start driving and the grasslands just keep rolling. Wildebeest, more wildebeest, now some bull elephants, waterbuck, oryx, buffalo, warthog, and now a pod of hippos frolicking in the mud. Occasionally a rocky outcrop interrupts the green landscape, a place where lions lounge and giraffe saunter past. It's a slow journey, every meter a reason to stop and get intimate with something new. By now the zebra are so commonplace that they hardly cause you to raise a glance. But the regular lion sightings never get tired. Find them hiding beneath trees, elegantly chasing wildebeest, stopping to inspect the safari truck, and playfully fighting in the high grass. Appreciating the Serengeti's scale requires a journey. The scenes keep repeating themselves and the incredible landscape never seems to end. More wildebeest, more cats, and more grassland that dazzles beneath the African sun; it's only on a journey like today's that the unrivaled beauty of the Serengeti can be realized. While many parks have the Big Five, nowhere delivers such abundant collections of Africa's mammals on such an epic scale. Your destination is a mobile camp, arguably the finest option for private immersion in the Serengeti.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti – Private Luxury in a Hidden Heart of the Serengeti
dayInfo.description: There are no fences in the Serengeti. There is no separation between you and the wild. You both become part of the landscape, a living breathing element of the Serengeti. Wake up and pull open the luxury tent curtains. A sprinkling of gazelle and elephants greet intrepid eyes. Is it time to get up? No, not just yet. Not when you can cuddle in bed and watch a tower of giraffe stroll past, or a big herd of buffalo slowly approach the camp. This private mobile camp is carefully erected in the heart of the wilderness, engulfing you in the Serengeti's charms and ensuring that you’re many, many miles from any other tourist or safari truck. Being mobile, the location of the camp is unlikely to have been experienced by anyone else before. And it's always likely to be in touching distance of the great wildebeest migration. It can sound a little scary, can't it? Being alone in the middle of lion country? There’s no need to worry; the local Maasai have coexisted with the big cats for thousands of years and your camp follows their generations’ old learning. Evening fires keep the big cats away, evidence of leopard prints is carefully followed, a scout keeps guard in case of any overly enthusiastic visitors, and any meat smells are carefully discarded. Complimenting this ancient style is a commitment to modern vacation luxury. Dining tables are erected on the grasslands, carefully selected wines are enjoyed from thick comfy chairs, solar panels provide electricity, and the bathroom facilities far surpass anything you could envisage in the bush. Of course, as you've come to expect, this is a camp by name, but luxurious home in reality. This is the Serengeti at its most authentic and intimate, but with an indulgent romantic twist. This is more than just a getaway; it's just you, your partner, a couple of discreet guides, and the whole of the Serengeti. While the camp is often attraction enough you also have three days of customized game drives. A leopard dips its neck and descends into the grass, stalking a small herd of unsuspecting kudu. Two boisterous male hippos fight for mating rights in shallow pools of water and mud. Lion cubs test their strength by play-fighting beneath a mother's watchful gaze, and a rampaging whirlwind of dust accompanies the wildebeest as they charge around the Serengeti, hooves galloping clear of the big cat patrol that follows at a discreet distance. This is every Serengeti game drive; wild, wonderful, and overloaded with unique sights. Breakfasts beside elephants, candlelit dinners surrounded by evocative silhouettes, zebras grazing beside your tent; these three days offer one of Africa's finest private safari experiences.

dayInfo.title: Kilimanjaro – Departure
dayInfo.description: You're in the heart of the wilderness so the wildebeest may need to be cleared from the tiny airstrip. A private micro flight takes you back across the Serengeti, affording more impressions of scale and dazzling aerial vistas. After landing at Kilimanjaro your international departure awaits. It's farewell to Tanzania and goodbye to both adventure and pure romantic escapism. Be sure to browse the safari tour reviews to Tanzania for ideas and real traveler reviews.

tourName: Ultimate Tanzania Luxury Safari
placesVisited: Arusha, Tarangire National Park, Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Northern Serengeti
generalInfo: Let Northern Tanzania’s ultimate safari destinations sweep you off your feet for nine days as you explore the diverse environments of Tarangire National Park, rich ecosystems of the Ngorongoro Conservation Area, and parched plains of the Northern Serengeti to discover the country’s fascinating flora and fauna. With decadence and glamour served at each safari camp across Tanzania, this tailored tour provides superior luxuries in the middle of the wild.

dayInfo.title: Arusha - Unwinding on the Banks of the Usa River
dayInfo.description: Tanzania’s safari starting point, Arusha, is a lively city standing pinned against the foothills of Mount Meru and Mount Kilimanjaro. As you fly over Tanzania towards the airport, you will admire its vast belt of untamed bushveld and enormous clusters of rocky mountains. Arriving near Arusha, you will enjoy a brisk scenic transfer to your thatched country inn nestled in a dense forest flowing from the banks of the Usa River. Today, you will acclimate to your surroundings from the comfort of your safari retreat and embrace the grandeur of Tanzania’s wilderness.

dayInfo.title: Tarangire National Park - Ultimate Safari Sights in Tanzania
dayInfo.description: Your safari across Northern Tanzania will truly begin today once you arrive at the gates of Tarangire National Park, a spectacular wildlife sanctuary set within the Manyara region’s granite ridge-covered landscapes and diverse mixed-vegetative environments. You will relish a game drive the minute you arrive, as your knowledgeable ranger leads you through the rich reserve to waterholes where all sorts of herbivores gather peacefully and observation decks overlooking bushveld where animals roam free. From lions lazily lounging in the shade of acacias to elephants standing beneath baobabs, you will snap up pictures of Tanzania’s ultimate safari sights.

dayInfo.title: Tarangire National Park - New Perspectives of Tanzania
dayInfo.description: Today, you will explore Tarangire from a new vantage as you wander from camp across the cool bushveld alongside an armed ranger. Your experienced tracker will point out animal footprints, and you will step into the shoes of the wildlife as you follow their tracks and survey evidence of the previous night’s activities. You will witness rhinos, giraffes, and much more standing a few meters away from you and discover the smallest inhabitants of Tarangire as you kneel next to green shrubbery. In the evening, you will cruise Tarangire with spotlights and peer through the dark to discover nocturnal Tanzania.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Conservation Area - Cruising through the Ngorongoro Crater
dayInfo.description: Following your thrilling safari tour through Tarangire, you will transfer to a gorgeous tented glamping site perched on the rim of the massive Ngorongoro Crater and commanding views of the postcard-worthy highland area. You may explore the conservation area alongside a professional game ranger after unpacking your things, with the hope of spotting lion prides slowly crossing the dry caldera and long-limbed serval cats hunting mice in the long grass. Your safari will culminate with sundowners and panoramas of the region’s rolling bushveld.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Conservation Area - Greetings from the Maasai Villagers
dayInfo.description: Today, you will be thrilled to discover more of Ngorongoro on guided game drives across the lush landscapes. Along the way, you will encounter much more fascinating wildlife and catch glimpses of unique plant life thriving in Tanzania’s diverse ecosystems before you make your way to a traditional Maasai village, where you will meet the friendly native tribe. The locals will share insight into their pastoral life and showcase generational performances as well as their distinct delicacies, allowing you to immerse yourself in the African culture and learn a great deal about their humble way of life.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Sun-Baked Serengeti Savannas
dayInfo.description: A short domestic flight stands between you and the sought-after Serengeti savannas, an illustrious golden landscape home to some of the world’s greatest wildlife spectacles. You will transfer across the sun-baked plains to a spectacular five-star safari lodge tucked amongst the Kogakuria Kopje rocks and boasting panoramas of the surrounding bushveld. Today, you may partake in a welcome game drive that will showcase the Serengeti’s unspoiled beauty or unwind with the help of your accommodation’s top-class amenities, as well as revel in uninterrupted stargazing this evening.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Discover Africa’s Big Five
dayInfo.description: Game drives in the Serengeti allow you to explore its diverse environments and encounter the curious creatures pacing the plains. Today, you will partake in morning and afternoon safari excursions across the reserve’s pristine wilderness and capture stunning photography of the free-roaming wildlife. From massive rhinos grazing the grasslands to gigantic elephants plodding across the river banks, stealthy leopards seeking refuge in shady acacias to lazy lions wandering the savanna, and herds of buffalo gathering around waterholes, all of Africa’s Big Five can be found in the Serengeti.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - More Magnificent Animal Sightings
dayInfo.description: Spotting Africa’s Big Five is a bucket list activity you will hope to accomplish by the end of your Northern Tanzania safari, and you may take some time today to tick it off during more ultimate game drive experiences. Once you have come across the Big Five, you will be on the keen lookout for other renowned and rare sightings, including the Aardvark and Pangolin, to name a few. You will also admire the colorful birdlife soaring across the Serengeti sky and spot birds of prey gliding across the baby blue.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Iconic Images of the Sprawling Serengeti
dayInfo.description: Images of the Northern Serengeti’s parched savannas and acacia-peppered plains will greet you in the morning as you step out onto your patio. You will watch animals wander the sparse bushveld from your doorstep and hear their faint echoes permeating across the grassy pastures while you sip on a steamy cup of coffee or tea. Today, you will enjoy a breakfast against a backdrop of these breathtaking scenes and one final Serengeti safari before you collect your things and transfer to the airport to catch your flight home.

tourName: Unparalleled East Africa Safari Trip of a Lifetime
placesVisited: Volcanoes National Park, Lewa Conservancy, Nairobi, Masai Mara, Northern Serengeti, Kigali, Ngorongoro Crater
generalInfo: Find yourself immersed in the drama and prestige of the wilderness during your 16-day luxury African safari through Kenya, Tanzania, and Rwanda. Discover the expansive splendor of the Serengeti as you search for golden lions and scour the jungle terrain of Volcanoes National Park to find lounging gorillas. Witness the rolling thunder of the Great Wildebeest Migration and embrace the elegance of giraffes towering above the trees. From opulent lodges to exclusive activities, you will experience the true depth and exceptional personalized service of a custom-tailored African safari during your trip of a lifetime.

dayInfo.title: Nairobi - Arrive in Kenya’s Dynamic Capital City
dayInfo.description: The color of adventure paints Nairobi with preserved images of colonial architecture divided by the cosmopolitan ambiance of skyscrapers and urban sprawl. The boundaries of the city feel as though they abruptly end, turning into the celebrated wilderness for which the country's rural expanse is known. Vibrant cultural life emanates from the active cafes and pulsing nightclubs as restaurants embrace local diversity with blends of traditional ingredients and customary recipes with an international flair. Your flight will land at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport, where your private transfer will meet you at customs. You will check into the splendor of Giraffe Manor, a luxury boutique hotel nestled into 12 acres of protected landscape connected to a greater 140 acres of indigenous forest. You can bask in the elegant ambiance of your room as Rothschild’s giraffe wander the grounds and feed on the towering Croton megalocarpus that can grow up to 118 feet tall. The remainder of the day will be at your leisure to enjoy the beauty of the hotel grounds and the unique allure of Nairobi. For insight into the nation’s culture, you can visit the National Museum where exhibits celebrate the Birds of East Africa or the prestige of Kenya’s ethnological wonders captured in a Kalenjin cloak made from Sykes Monkeys. You could also visit the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust to learn how the center cares for abandoned young elephants and rhinos with the aim of releasing them back to the wild.

dayInfo.title: Lewa Conservancy - Transfer to Stellar Northern Kenya
dayInfo.description: At breakfast, you can bask in the aromas of freshly brewed coffee and buttery pastries as Rothschild’s giraffes peer through the windows of the English-style manor and possibly dip their long necks through the windows in search of a treat. Your private transfer will meet you in the hotel lobby after breakfast and escort you to the airport for your flight to Lewa Conservancy. The protected landscape spans thousands of acres of open savanna spreading across northern Kenya and remains a popular destination for viewing Grevy’s zebra, elephants, cheetah, and over 400 species of bird. After your flight, your private transfer will meet you at the Lewa airstrip and escort you to the delights of Sirikoi House where unrivaled exclusivity awaits. The pristine lodge rises above 68,000 acres of surrounding wilderness resembling a chic eco-friendly African home immersed in a sense of welcoming luxury. Your introduction to game drives at Lewa Conservancy will take you off-road closing the often large distance between you and the wildlife as you search for elephants, rhinos, and zebra. After enjoying a view of the sweeping plains falling away from the Mount Kenya highlands, your guide will lead you on an immersive game drive where the scent of grass and wet soil will fill the air. You may find a herd of the endangered Grevy zebra grazing on the brush. They can grow up to nine feet long and has a distinctive mule-like look. You can experience the unique wonders of a private night game drive in search of nocturnal wildlife, as well featuring the wilderness from a completely different perspective.

dayInfo.title: Lewa Conservancy - Discover the Exciting Wilderness
dayInfo.description: Each day, your program is determined by you, and there are many options. For a distinctive experience, you can travel to the Ngare Ndare Forest for a different perspective of the landscape. Move from the low-lying plains to the dense indigenous trees at the base of Mount Kenya to wander the nearly four miles of trails to reach the mighty crash of the seven famous waterfalls and rock pools. The azure water, echoing trickle, and verdant vines will juxtapose the parched plains before you venture into treetops, reaching upwards of 328 feet above the forest floor for possible sightings of elephants grazing on the branches or leopards sleeping in the trees. You might prefer to experience Conservation in Action for a behind the scenes excursion into the day-to-day conservation and anti-poaching operations of Sirikoi House inside the Lewa Conservancy. Learn how the Tracker Dog unit of rangers and dogs discourage, track, and prevent poaching for wildlife such as elephants and rhinos. You could also visit the surrounding communities to witness the many efforts to teach children about the ecological challenges facing their future from outreach in schools, clubs, and workshops directly leading to conservation efforts with game drives and visits to the education center.

dayInfo.title: Masai Mara - Travel and Embrace Unspoilt Backdrop
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you have plenty of options in how you wish to experience the wonderful wilderness around you. You can wake early for a game drive that explores the remarkable landscape or relax in the comfort of the deck with an “arm-chair” safari watching as wildlife comes to you. You can partake in a walking safari, horseback ride across the vast plains, or zoom around the landscape on a quad bike safari. A helicopter excursion can take you to the top of Mount Kenya for a fly-fishing expedition or northbound to find lakes flooded with shimmering pink flamingos. After you return from your chosen adventure, you will have a private transfer to the airstrip for your flight bound for the renowned Masai Mara National Reserve. You will travel with a private driver from the airstrip to reach Cottars 1920’s Safari Camp for a taste of vintage luxury at its best overlooking a private conservancy that spans 7,608 acres. The luxury camp is run by one of the oldest established safari families in Africa and captures the romantic spirit and adventure of a luxury safari in an authentic natural environment.

dayInfo.title: Masai Mara - Revel in Maasai Mara National Reserve
dayInfo.description: In the early hours of the morning, you will venture out into the wilds of one of the Masai Mara’s most remote regions. The cold air before sunrise will bite at your nose as the open-air vehicle wanders the dirt tracks with your guide searching for an unparalleled view of the pristine wildlife at a leisurely pace. You may hear the bone-rattling roar of a lion as it shows its power to encroaching males in the area to protect its pride and position. Their magnificent roar can be heard echoing up to five miles away. After you return to the camp and indulge in a delicious breakfast surrounded by the untouched wilderness of the reserve, you can explore the beauty of the Masai Mara with a waterfall swimming excursion plunging into the cool freshwater pool hidden by expansive plains or participate in the unique experience of the life of a hunter-gatherer in the Masai Mara. Your guide will uncover the traditions of the untamed bush and wild savanna as you learn about the customs of the El Dorobo and Maasai tribe who use the land and wildlife in their daily lives. From learning how to track a nearby animal based on traces left in the grass to learning the medicinal and dental hygienic properties of plants like the Euclea Divinorum , you will see the Masai Mara from a different perspective.

dayInfo.title: Masai Mara - Experience Kenya’s Majestic Wildlife
dayInfo.description: The wonders of the wildlife in the Masai Mara are visible year-round but between September and October, the landscape constantly hums with the constant beat of hooves stemming from the great migration as millions of wildebeest, zebra, and antelope cross the borders between the Masai Mara and Serengeti. After a morning game drive, you can experience the marvels of the landscape and wildlife from a different perspective on a hot-air balloon safari. The average hot air balloon hovers between 1,000 and 3,000 feet giving you the ultimate panorama of the Masai Mara landscape. During the Great Migration, you may witness the sea of wildebeest traveling across the plains or winding through the wide reaches of the nearby river as they trudge through the water to reach the opposite banks absent of crocodiles or hippo pods from high in teh sky. You will learn why experiencing the Great Migration is one of the world’s most exciting wilderness encounters as your guide explains the annual movement and biological allure of the wildebeest, as well as the dynamic ecosystem created with their journey while the scent of crips fresh air surrounds you.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Travel to the Mara Riverbanks
dayInfo.description: After your early morning game drive, bask in the soothing comforts of your luxurious breakfast. Your private transfer will then take you to the airstrip to begin your journey to the Northern Serengeti and the remote beauty of the Singita Mara River Tented Camp. Renowned for its exclusivity and incredible service, the site is accentuated by covered walkways and decks that offer prolific game viewing. Enjoy the sounds of rushing water, the breeze whipping at the tall grass, and the mighty roar of the migrating wildebeest and zebra. The vast grassland of the Northern Serengeti has fewer crowds as it sits nestled between the famous Central Serengeti and the renowned Masai Mara National Reserve. The remote corner of the protected landscape will immerse you in green rolling hills and granite outcrops with fragrant woodlands bursting with acacia trees and the savanna's open expanse. Massive herds of wildebeest swarm the plains during the migration across the Mara River’s crocodile-infested waters while elephants thrive in the secluded area to create the highest concentration of herds in the Serengeti. After settling into the comforts of your luxurious space, you may find a herd of elephants parading near the edge of the Mara River. In the evening, indulge in the opulence of your camp with a wine tasting that features influential collectors and sought-after private reserves tailored to your tastes for an exceptional embellishment to your remote panoramic view.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Enjoy the Thrills of the Wild
dayInfo.description: In the morning, discover the wonders of the wilderness as you begin the day with an early game drive. Your guide will lead you along the banks of the Mara River to explore the exceptional ecosystem. You may find hippos presiding over a small area of the river a dozen hiding from the harsh sunlight in the water to protect their sensitive skin. The scent of wet grass may fill the air as your guide searches for rare oribi, a small antelope with rusty brown fur and a white throat. You may also keep your eyes wide open for spottings of the rare and endangered black rhino, which grazes on the bushes and trees. They grow to over five feet tall and tower over the open grasses of the vast plain. When you return to camp, you will have your exceptional breakfast waiting for you as the scent of fresh berries may overtake the prevailing aroma of the fresh river water carried in the breeze.

dayInfo.title: Northern Serengeti - Traverse Tanzania’s Stunning Beauty
dayInfo.description: As you explore the untamed wilderness of the isolated Northern Serengeti and its more remote corners, you may find the heavy concentration of crocodile teeming in the Mara River. The Nile crocodile can reach 16.4 feet long and thrives during the Great Migration as wildebeest unknowingly splash into the water while the crocodile waits unseen in the current. As you travel the riverbanks and through the open plains during the migration season, you may find herds of wildebeests falling prey to the cunning crocodiles or witness the splashing of a zebra escapes the predator’s waiting jaws. You can opt for a walking safari, and your guide will get you closer to the intimate details of the wilderness and wildlife that are often overlooked when moving quickly through the plains. The excursion will give you a quietly thrilling experience as you walk through the tall grass at a slower pace to find signs of wildlife you may not have noticed before. Your guide will reveal a quieter side of the safari that allows you to hear the snap of a crocodile’s mouth on the water’s edge or search for an elephant tearing at a tree in the distance.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro - Travel to Stunning Ngorongoro Crater
dayInfo.description: You will travel from the northern Serengeti to the Ngorongoro Crater in the morning, where the 100-square-mile caldera reveals over 25,000 large mammals. As your private driver leads you into the crater, you will find one of the world’s best-preserved calderas and an unparalleled assembly of wildlife. From the rare black rhino to one of the highest density of lion, your eyes will scarcely be able to take it all in. After enjoying this wildlife highlight, you will check-in to the grandeur of andBeyond Ngorongoro Crater Lodge, which is nestled into the elevated side of the caldera. The boutique accommodation hosts a collection of handcrafted mud and thatch suites raised on stilts. Each offers a remarkable panorama across the sunken landscape as modern luxury blends with traditional Maasai design. After a scenic descent into the crater, you can bask in the beauty of your surroundings with a personalized banquet on the crater floor. A private butler will accentuate the comforts of your luxurious picnic set with a view of the wild plants tangling along the steep crater slopes and shimmering waters of the distant lake. You may see troupes of zebras grazing nearby as the scent of crisp melons and lime overtakes the table.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro - Wander Marvelous Ngorongoro Crater
dayInfo.description: Your morning game drive through Ngorongoro Crater will reveal the splendor of the protected wildlife and landscape. With sweeping views that range from the sight of black rhino to the light pink feathers of lesser flamingo, much is reflected in the glassy surface of the nearby water. Your guide will give you fantastic insight into the wildlife you spot during your drive, from the diet of the flamingo that turns their feathers pink to the reason you have the best chance of spotting the rare black rhino during your excursion through the ancient crater. As the sun fades over the horizon, return to camp to experience the unique sounds of African drums accompanied by a cocktail. A group of local musicians will fill the evening sky with the rhythm and pulse of drumbeats bringing a melody of traditional Tanzanian culture to the forefront accompanied by the mbira. The punctuating tones of the marimba-like instrument will define the beat as the musicians perform at the lodge with a view sweeping across the tremendous landscape for an unforgettable evening of music, excitement, and culture.

dayInfo.title: Kigali - Fly from Tanzania to Kigali, Rwanda
dayInfo.description: Your private transfer will arrive in the morning for your flight bound for Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. The inviting cultural center of the country, the city spans the surrounding ridges and valleys with neighborhoods characterized by flowing streets, winding boulevards, and blossoming trees. Both contemporary and charismatic in cosmopolitan design, the mountains enclose the charming city crowned by the looming peak of Mount Kigali at nearly 6,070 feet above sea level. Upon arrival, your private transfer will meet you at Kigali International Airport and escort you to the beautiful grounds of The Retreat by Heaven, an eco-friendly resort that teems with opulence. From private terraces to a saltwater pool, farm-to-table dining to exceptional luxury villas, the luxury will know no bounds. The remainder of the day will be at your leisure to delight in the comforts of your retreat, or you might opt to discover what many consider to be one of the continent’s cleanest and safest cities. For a unique look at the nation's contemporary and historical culture, you can visit the Kigali Genocide Memorial. Your emotional visit will offer greater insight into the complexities of Rwanda with a short film exploring the genocide and three permanent exhibitions with artifacts, historical information, and photos that portray the events. The stained-glass windows decorating the space give the memorial a consecrated atmosphere while the sculptures create a deeper resonance.

dayInfo.title: Volcanoes National Park - Travel to Cherished Scenery
dayInfo.description: After a leisurely breakfast, continue your journey as you fly via helicopter from the Kigali Airport to an airstrip near Volcanoes National Park. With a warm welcome, your private guide will escort you through some incredible scenery. Volcanoes National Park is wedged against the borders of the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda and overtakes five volcanoes that spread across nearly 62 square miles. The dense jungle terrain blankets the slopes of the Virunga Mountains and provides the perfect ecosystem for the rare mountain gorillas. With rambling hiking trails and the shores of the glassy Mount Bisate crater lake, the natural beauty is impressive as you arrive at Bisate Lodge. Find comfort in your private view of the natural amphitheater that has been shaped by the eroded volcanic cone. The natural drama of your view is a perfect introduction to the grandeur of your accommodations. Your luxury villa maximizes comfort, panoramic views, and are a reflection of regional rural culture. For deeper insight into the region's cultural and biological connection with mountain gorillas, you can take a guided hike to visit the grave of Dian Fossey, climbing to an elevation of 9,842 feet above sea level. The famous primatologist studied and protected the wild gorillas of Rwanda, and her resting place memorializes her courage, passion, and dedication to the region nestled into the saddle of two volcanoes.

dayInfo.title: Volcanoes National Park - Search for Famous Gorillas
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the aroma of freshly ground coffee will fill the dining room with hints of caramel and brown sugar. Before you venture into the wilderness with your guide, you can partake in a short visit to the tree nursery that supports the reforestation project. The subtle aroma of cedar will fill the air as your guide explains the project's importance as one of the most devastating factors in the endangerment of the mountain gorilla stems from deforestation. There are approximately 1,000 mountain gorillas left in the world, and your guide will take you through the dense jungle and undulating volcanic slopes in search of one of the region’s 12 habituated troupes. As the morning mist dissipates as the sunlight fills the treetops, your hike will provide an exciting challenge to find gorillas in their natural habitat. You may hear the gorilla troupe before you see them as they pull leaves from the surrounding trees or as the matriarch hoots waiting for the silverback to return the call from up to half a mile away.

dayInfo.title: Volcanoes National Park - Enjoy a Day at Leisure
dayInfo.description: Your final day in the wilderness is yours to explore, relax, and appreciate the surrounding wonders at your preferred pace. You can venture to the top of Mount Bisoke at 12,175 feet for a stunning view of the crater lake or visit the local community to meet members of the farm cooperative. For another fascinating wildlife experience, you could follow your guide into the heart of the bamboo forest in search of the golden monkey. The dense foliage may cloud the sky and cover the forest floor along the base of Mount Sabyinyo. The sprightly character of the golden monkey will bring to light their unique personalities as the sporadic sunlight glints against the hints of red and gold fur along their backs. They can grow up to 26 inches and can live in groups of up to 62 individuals. You may find them racing across the bamboo canopy above you as they forage for fruits or weave together sections of shoots to form a sleeping canopy.

dayInfo.title: Volcanoes National Park - Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you can bask in the incredible view of the surrounding valley and ridges as you settle into the comforting aroma of freshly brewed coffee. You may glimpse the bronze sunbird to find its sheer plumage glinting in the sunlight with shades of green, orange, and black or spot the Rowenzori side-striped chameleon whose vivid green skin nearly blends against the lush foliage. After breakfast, your private transfer will take you to the Ruhengeri Airport for your return helicopter flight to Kigali, where you will continue the journey home bringing an end to your African safari trip of a lifetime.

tourName: Untouched East Africa: 11-Day Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda
placesVisited: Arusha, Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Serengeti National Park, Masai Mara, Entebbe, Bwindi, Kigali
generalInfo: East Africa’s wilderness is largely untouched, and sweeping savannas dominate massive slices of the region’s pristine wilderness. You will explore and admire these landscapes for 11 days, discovering the best that East Africa has to offer. From Tanzania’s thrilling safari scenes to Kenya’s enchanting wildlife encounters as well as Uganda’s historic culture and extraordinary experiences, such as gorilla tracking, embrace the wilderness wonders of these picturesque African paradises.

dayInfo.title: Arusha - Tanzania’s Gateway to Paradise
dayInfo.description: Arusha is a gateway to northeastern Tanzania’s decorated wilderness, a collection of untouched safari environments sweeping Mount Meru’s foothills and Mount Kilimanjaro’s looming summits. Today, you will transfer from the airport to a charming accommodation stationed at the base of Mount Meru’s volcanic peaks and spend your afternoon acclimating to Arusha’s cultural cityscape. You may also relish a tour of the surrounding landscape, where you will admire the astonishing snow-capped crest of Kilimanjaro, a postcard scene of Tanzania, or a culinary exposé of Arusha’s decadent local delicacies.

dayInfo.title: Ngorongoro Conservation Area - All Things African Safari
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, you will pack your things and prepare for your first adventures within Tanzania’s immaculate wilderness environments. Cruising across roads weaving through lime-green hills to viewpoints pinned on the precipices of towering gorges, you will begin to embrace the epic scale and phenomenal wildlife paradise that is the Ngorongoro Conservation Area. Your safari through the semi-nomadic lands of the local Maasai people will lead you to spot iconic collections of game, including Africa’s Big Five, as well as admire scenes of massive gatherings of wildebeest and zebra migrating across the grasslands.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti National Park - Entrancing Introductions to East Africa’s Savannas
dayInfo.description: The Serengeti’s vast savannas are an archetypal East African safari scene you will treasure as you arrive in the destination’s protected national park and slowly meander across the mesmerizing landscapes to your accommodation hemmed in the wilderness alongside a peaceful waterhole. After a thrilling safari across the Serengeti, you will return to camp and watch the animals come and go while the sun descends over the horizon and the stars puncture the night sky. These quiet evenings will be an extraordinary backdrop for your delightful campfire dinners.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti National Park - Staggering Scenes of the Great Migration
dayInfo.description: Besides its impressive collection of wildlife thriving across the distinct terrain covering its sprawling conservation area, the Serengeti’s ultimate claim to fame is the Great Migration. Generally occurring between July and October, you may witness the world’s greatest natural spectacle if arriving at the park during the appropriate time of year. Regardless of the iconic running of millions of wildebeest and zebra across the Serengeti, several exceptional migration moments occur during the year, and you may spot the incredible river crossings or enormous gatherings during your safaris across the reserve.

dayInfo.title: Serengeti National Park - Capturing the Special Serengeti Scenes
dayInfo.description: With another full day to explore the Serengeti, you will set off early in the morning to capture images of big cats hunting before dawn. With leopards, lions, and cheetahs having the eyesight advantage over prey under cover of night, you may be lucky enough to spot a kill in action or catch the cats tucking into their meals after a hard-fought morning of hunting. In the afternoon, you will retreat to river banks to watch colorful birdlife hovering between branches and gigantic hippos plunging in the river’s ribbons of water.

dayInfo.title: Masai Mara - Sensational Wilderness Scenes in Southwestern Kenya
dayInfo.description: Along the Tanzanian border in southwestern Kenya, the Masai Mara National Reserve’s preserved savannas unroll endlessly towards the horizon. You will transfer to the coveted destination this morning and appreciate these scenes en route to your delightful accommodation hidden within groves of acacia trees. Flanking a natural waterhole, animals will wander freely in and around camp while you capture them with high-tech photography equipment from your patio. You will join a knowledgeable ranger upon arriving and venture through Masai Mara to discover the wildlife highlights lying beyond the borders of camp.

dayInfo.title: Masai Mara - A Safari Adventure of Cultural Importance
dayInfo.description: You will enjoy another day of Masai Mara adventure alongside a spirited and knowledgeable ranger who will share information about the immaculate region and its intriguing wildlife. After a wealth of beautiful safari discovery, you will arrive at an authentic tribal village poised on the hills cascading Masai Mara’s ancient landscapes. The traditional villagers will welcome you and invite you to watch customary performances as well as tuck into local delicacies. You will come to learn a great deal about their humble origins and semi-nomadic way of life as the residents accept you and demonstrate their unique traditions.

dayInfo.title: Entebbe - Admire Uganda’s History and Cultural Heritage
dayInfo.description: Arriving at the lakeside town of Entebbe, you will be swept away by the views of shimmering azure waters wrapping around chartreuse-colored shores home to vibrant Ugandan districts that will introduce you to the country’s local culture. You may spend your afternoon in Entebbe appreciating the simple local way of life during strolls around spirited neighborhoods to museums and eateries sharing the town’s heritage and culinary culture. In the evening, you will watch the fiery African sunset from your secluded balcony and reminisce about your stellar safari discoveries in East Africa thus far.

dayInfo.title: Bwindi - The Gorilla Guardians of Bwindi
dayInfo.description: Spreading across southwestern Uganda, Bwindi Impenetrable National Park is an impressive protected area encompassing one of the country’s most exquisite forests. Running along the edge of the Albertine Rift, the emerald forest is nourished by the colossal bodies of water, and its proliferating tree life houses an extraordinary array of wildlife, birdlife, and plant life. Today, you will embrace the wonders of Bwindi at leisure before meeting the Gorilla Guardians of Bwindi, a group of gorilla doctors dedicating their lives to the protection of the region’s astonishing primates.

dayInfo.title: Bwindi - Awe-Inspiring Gorilla Trekking through the Greenery
dayInfo.description: The highlight of Bwindi is a gorilla trekking tour through the lush greenery that will allow you to get up close to the impressive primates who dwell in this luxuriant forest and feed off the flourishing vegetation. You will be joined by an extremely professional ranger with an in-depth knowledge of the beasts, guiding you through your introductions with the curious creatures and shedding insight on their behaviors and the local doctors’ efforts to protect the region and its indigenous inhabitants.

dayInfo.title: Bwindi - Remarkable Recounts of Rwanda’s Dramatic Past
dayInfo.description: You will appreciate the panoramic views of Bwindi’s evergreen forests from the privacy of your terrace tucked beneath the shady trees before packing your belongings and transferring to the airport. En route, you will make a stop in Kigali to uncover significant Rwandan heritage at the Genocide Memorial. Receiving thousands of visitors each year, this iconic museum and final resting place for over 250,000 victims of the Rwandan genocide will share dramatic recounts of the devastating event through heart-wrenching exhibits and immensely insightful educational tours, an incredibly important final experience of your journey across East Africa.
